newsitem.title: UK: CU up as fresh bid talk creates squeeze.
newsitem.headline: CU up as fresh bid talk creates squeeze.

text.p: Shares in Commercial Union Plc were squeezed sharply higher for a second day on Friday in a strong insurance sector, as a fresh outbreak of bid speculation left market makers short of stock, traders and analysts said.
The stock was up 19p at 664 by 1104 GMT, near the intraday high for the year of 674p set January 29. Volume was a moderate 1.7 million shares.

"The rumour mill is churning out all sorts of stories," said David Hudson, analyst at Credit Lyonnais Laing, "the composites have been left behind as the financials have been leading the market up, and it's time for them to catch up."
"Add a few rumours and that prevents any sellers."
Elsewhere in the composite insurance sector, Royal Sun Alliance Plc was up 8p at 426-1/2 and General Accident Plc rose 7-1/2p at 732-1/2.

Speculation yesterday of a bid from a continental European bank or insurance group was joined today by talk that ABN Amro could be interested in CU's Dutch unit Delta Lloyd, traders and analysts said.

Yesterday CU shares rose 19p amid talk that BZW was preparing a research note, arguing that composite insurers were due a re-rating and that CU offered the best value in the sector, with a target price of over 800p.
Analysts at the brokerage were not immediately available for comment.
Separately NatWest on Thursday raised Guardian Royal Exchange Plc, up 6-/2p at 271-1/2, to "add" from "hold."
Traders said recent upgrades and bid talk had created a stock shortage, squeezing prices higher.
"The market has been caught short and it is all a bit squeezy," said one market-maker.
